hear.translation[0].definitions[0].defin: to know that a sound is being made, using your ears
hear.translation[0].definitions[0].examp: She heard a sudden loud crash.
Did anyone see or hear anything last night?
I could hear the sound of traffic.
Old Zeke doesn’t hear too well anymore.
somebody doesn’t hear too well/very well
Jenny could hear them arguing outside.
I couldn’t hear what they were saying most of the time.
She didn’t want to be heard to criticize him.
hear.translation[0].definitions[1].defin: to listen to what someone is saying, the music they are playing etc
hear.translation[0].definitions[1].examp: Maggie did not wait to hear an answer.
Did you hear that programme on whales the other night?
I hear what you say, but I don’t think we should rush this decision.
I hear what you say/what you’re saying
I want to hear what the doctor has to say.
hear.translation[0].definitions[2].defin: to be told or find out a piece of information
hear.translation[0].definitions[2].examp: I heard a rumor that he was getting married soon.
I’ve heard it said that they met in Italy.
We don’t hear anything of him these days.
hear anything/much of somebody/something
There’s a nasty infection going round, so I hear.
so I hear/so I’ve heard
I’m so sorry to hear he died.
hear (that)
She’ll be pleased to hear that she can leave hospital tomorrow.
hear (that)
Teresa heard about the decision later.
hear about
I’ve heard of a job which would be just right for you.
hear of
This was the first I’d heard of any trouble in the area  (=I had just heard news of trouble for the first time).
hear of
He was last heard of in Washington  (=he was in Washington the last time someone had information about him).
hear of
Did you hear what happened to Julia?
hear what/how/who etc
hear.translation[0].definitions[3].defin: to listen to all the facts in a case in a court of law in order to make a legal decision
hear.translation[0].definitions[3].examp: The Supreme Court heard the case on Tuesday.
hear.translation[0].note_box[0].items[0]: In meanings 1,2, and 3, hear is not usually used in the progressive You say
I was hearing a strange sound
hear.translation[0].note_box[0].items[1]: Hear is often used with can
I could hear a strange sound
hear.translation[0].note_box[0].items[2]: In spoken English, people sometimes say I’m hearing to talk about something they have been told recently, especially more than once
I’ve been hearing some nice things about you
hear.translation[0].note_box[1].sections: hear
to know that a sound is being made, using your ears
There’s no need to shout – I can hear you!
Voices could be heard in the distance.
listen
to pay attention to something, using your ears
I was listening to the news on the car radio.
He never listens to anything I say.
make out
to hear something with difficulty
When I got closer, I could make out a human voice.
I could just make out what he was saying.
overhear
to accidentally hear another person’s conversation
I overheard her say to her friend that she had lost something.
catch
to hear something that someone says
Sorry, I didn’t catch your name.
I caught the last few minutes of the programme.
tune in
to listen to a programme – often used in announcements on the radio
Tune in for all the latest news and views from around the world.
Thousands of people tune in to the show every week.
audible
loud enough to be heard
Her words were clearly audible.
an audible whisper
hear.translation[0].note_box[2].heading: USAGE: Hear or listen?
hear.translation[0].note_box[2].items[0]: Don’t confuse hear (=a sound comes into your ears) with listen to (=hear and pay attention to something)
hear.translation[0].note_box[2].items[1]: You should listen to my advice
hear.translation[0].note_box[2].items[2]: I lay in bed listening to music
I lay in bed hearing music
